channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Piers Morgan hammers Care Minister Helen Whately
item.description: Care Minister Helen Whately this morning said the UK government is currently changing the way it collects data in relation to deaths caused by the coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Oxford University vaccine trials start this week
item.description: Matt Hancock today said he would give £20million in funding to the scientists developing the vaccine and was pushing forward the attempt to become the first country in the world to create a vaccine.

item.title: Sales of barbecue food soar as Britain prepares to bask in 75F mini heatwave
item.description: Temperatures will hit 71F (22C) today for many parts of the country - but London is forecast to see even more warm weather and sunshine on Thursday as the heatwave continues.

item.title: Fury from Dominic Raab over mandarin claim over EU procurement scheme
item.description: The government is facing fresh questions about the behind-the-scenes manoeuvring in the wake of extraordinary comments by Foreign Office mandarin Sir Simon McDonald.

item.title: Tenants refused 20% rent cut on luxury east London flats
item.description: More than 100 residents in Shacklewell, east London, requested a 10 per cent reduction in rent from Tower Quay properties amid the coronavirus pandemic - but had their request turned down.

item.title: Heartbroken family of missing estate agent Chelsie Dack fear she may have killed herself
item.description: Chelsie Dack's mother Dawn Howell shared an online post that said it is 'strongly believed Chelsie has taken her own life'. Chelsie reported missing from her home in Gorleston on Monday.

item.title: Motorist captures images of 'muscular big cat' thought to be a puma roaming the British countryside
item.description: The photos match other sightings of big cats in Bowness-on-Windermere, totalling more than 40 since 2003. The woman said the puma was eating a pigeon when she spotted it and took three pictures.

item.title: Last year was Europe's hottest year EVER recorded
item.description: Figures from the European state of the climate report from the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) also reveals 11 of the 12 warmest years on record for the continent occurred since 2000.

item.title: Former Olympic rower says coronavirus patients were dying minutes after removing their oxygen masks
item.description: Former Olympic rower Kenny Dwan, 71, from London said on GMB that coronavirus patients were 'going home in black bags' ten minutes after removing their oxygen masks.

item.title: Stephen Hawking´s ventilator donated to NHS to help in coronavirus fight
item.description: The physicist, who had motor neurone disease, died in 2018, aged 76 and received care from the Royal Papworth and Addenbrooke hospitals in Cambridge.

item.title: London transport network is a WEEK from running out of cash, Sadiq Khan reveals
item.description: The Mayor of London last night revealed there had been a 95 per cent reduction in Tube use and an 85 per cent fall in numbers on buses following the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Selfish shoppers hog supermarket delivery slots leaving needy waiting
item.description: Many vulnerable families say they are being forced to stay up into the small hours to try to secure a delivery spot as soon as they become available. Even then, they are not always successful.

item.title: Tracey Cox tells why forbidding sex could revitalise your relationship
item.description: Sex expert Tracey Cox reveals why forbidding sex could actually help your relationship and says a ban on intercourse could make it more appealing to both you and your partner in the long run.

item.title: Why drinking too much TEA during lockdown is bad for you, expert claims
item.description: Dr Grace Farhat, a lecturer in food science and nutrition at Liverpool Hope University, told FEMAIL Brits should stick to four to five cups of tea a day while marooned in their homes due to coronavirus.

item.title: Daughter who 'never stopped laughing' dies of coronavirus before her father could say his goodbye
item.description: The heartbroken dad of a 'loving daughter who never stopped laughing' has paid tribute to her after she tragically passed away aged just 22 after contracting coronavirus.

item.title: India Hicks shares her glamorous life in lockdown in the Bahamas
item.description: Prince Charles' goddaughter has shared a peek at her life a she isolates with her family at their home on the sun-soaked island of the Bahamas.

item.title: Grieving mum slams thug who hacked her son, 17, to death
item.description: Kyle Yule, 17, was fatally stabbed in October 2017 near his home in Gillingham, Kent when five thugs hunted him to his friend's front door before savagely attacking him with knives and machetes.

item.title: Over-50s should stay at home during the coronavirus crisis - and overweight Britons are at risk
item.description: Mike Fischer CBE, who runs a medical research lab in Oxford, warned the actions of those in their 50s and beyond will be 'critical' for the NHS.

item.title: Philip Pullman says UK government should face 'conspiracy to murder' charges
item.description: Philip Pullman, 73, called for the government to face 'conspiracy to murder' charges if it is revealed the UK rejected an EU scheme to buy huge quantities of PPE for 'Brexit-related reasons'.

item.title: Sale singer Beth Palmer, 17, took her life during coronavirus lockdown
item.description: The parents of 17-year-old Beth Palmer, a talented singer from Sale in Greater Manchester, are warning of the dangers lockdown is having on young people's mental health after their daughter took her own life.

item.title: 12 shipwrecks uncovered in the east Med dating from 300 BC
item.description: A British-led expedition has uncovered 12 shipwrecks in the eastern Mediterranean sea, including one colossal 17th century ship containing porcelain, jugs and illicit tobacco pipes.

item.title: Tony Blair warns decisions on coronavirus lockdown must be taken NOW
item.description: Tony Blair said Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab and senior ministers must make crucial choices on releasing schools, regions and sectors to avoid huge damage to the economy.

item.title: Stargazers get incredible sight of Lyrid meteor shower
item.description: The Lyrids takes its name from the constellation of Lyra the Harp, where the shooting stars appear to originate from. The celestial display peaked last night and was visible until early this morning.

item.title: Desperate appeal after heartless thieves steal flags and pictures from WWII memorial
item.description: Thieves snatched tributes to 10 US airmen from Endcliffe Park in Sheffield, where in 1944 the heroic servicemen crashed as he desperately swerved to avoid a group of children.

item.title: Experts become LESS influential after winning Nobel prize - especially in physics and medicine
item.description: The work of Nobel Prize winners published in the year after their win is less influential, say a research team led by Northwestern University (pictured, Welsh Nobel Prize winner Prof Brian Josephson).

item.title: Older pupils should return first in a phased reopening of Britain's schools says headteachers' union
item.description: The Association of School and College Leaders said older students in both primary and secondary schools have the most to gain. A phased return isn't expected until after half term in June at earliest.

item.title: Coronavirus tests given to NHS staff to let them return to work 'are FLAWED'
item.description: A leaked Public Health England document revealed testing centres had been told to stop using the kits because of 'quality assurance difficulties'.

item.title: Researchers examine engineering 'own' immune cells to target and destroy coronavirus-infected cells
item.description: A new commentary from Duke-NUS Medical School says engineering receptors on the body's own immune cells could get them to recognize and destroy cells infected with the novel coronavirus.

item.title: The number of women accusing Peter Nygard of sexual assault has increased FIVE-FOLD
item.description: The original lawsuit of 10 accusers was filed against the 78-year-old Canadian in February, when FBI raided his Manhattan office.

item.title: Man charged with murder after woman injured in 'road rage attack' dies in hospital with coronavirus
item.description: Robert Barrow, 54, allegedly drove over Tahereh Pirali-Dashti, 40, following an incident on a busy road in north London, in January. She died in hospital in April after contracting Covid-19.

item.title: Cops in Connecticut are testing a 'pandemic drone' to monitor people's temperatures
item.description: Police in Westport revealed Tuesday they are working with company Draganfly to test a 'pandemic drone' that can potentially monitor people with infectious respiratory conditions in public areas.

item.title: Guards say Iran successfully launches first military...
item.description: Iran said the satellite - dubbed the Nour - had been launched from the Qassed two-stage launcher from the Markazi desert, a vast expanse in Iran's central plateau (file photo).
item.media:description: A file picture shows Iran launching the Zafar satellite, which failed to reach orbit on February 9, 2020

item.title: Covid-Dictionary: What slang about the pandemic looks like around the world
item.description: Language experts at Babble have revealed to FEMAIL the top slang phrases about the coronavirus from across the globe, including covidiot or covidiota in the UK and Spain.

item.title: Delayed RAF plane lands in UK with only HALF the PPE promised because
item.description: An RAF transport plane carrying personal protective equipment (PPE) from Turkey has finally arrived in the UK.

item.title: Conor McGregor commended by a hospital in Ireland after donating equipment to help fight coronavirus
item.description: The UFC fighter has helped in the fight against the deadly disease by donating one million euros that has gone towards cardiac monitors, oxygen equipment and 50,000 masks for hospitals.

item.title: Adorable moment leopard tries to lead her cubs across a road - but they have other ideas
item.description: Thinus Delport, 64, captured the rare sight while visiting Kruger National Park in South Africa. He told his daughters to sing to entice the animals out and surprisingly it worked.

item.title: Coronavirus : Hydroxychloroquine drug led to higher death rates
item.description: About 28 percent of the 368 US veterans treated with hydroxychloroquine for coronavirus died of the virus, compared to just 11% of those who were given standard treatment, an NIH study has revealed.

item.title: Jellyfish is spotted swimming through Venice's unusually clean canals
item.description: Zoologist Andrea Mangoni filmed the creature swimming in 'exceptionally calm' waters near Venice's Bareteri Bridge last week.

item.title: Judge brands thug 'disgusting social menace' as he jails him for urinating on war memorial
item.description: Mark Smith, 58, was spotted on CCTV by council staff urinating on the cenotaph war memorial in St Peter's Square, Manchester, and he has since been jailed for more than two years.

item.title: Met Police to crackdown on motorists abusing London's clearer roads by speeding
item.description: The Metropolitan Police has promised to crackdown on speeding motorists who are abusing the clearer roads during the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Pandemic and chill: Netflix adds a cool 16M subscribers
item.description: California-based Netflix more than doubled its own projections for new customers in the first three months of this year as quarantined audiences binged on series such as Tiger King.
item.media:description: FILE - This Jan. 29, 2010, file photo shows the company logo and view of Netflix headquarters in Los Gatos, Calif. Netflix picked up nearly 16 million global subscribers during the first three months of the year, helping cement its status as one of the world's most essential services in times of isolation or crisis. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez, File)

item.title: Men's rights activist whose mother was murdered by abusive husband thinks feminism is a 'problem'
item.description: German men's rights activist Philipp Tanzer, 42, of Durness, said in a BBC Three documentary that he still thinks feminism is a problem, despite his own mother being shot by her abusive husband.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: FTSE 100 opens up despite oil price plunge
item.description: The FTSE 100 index rose today despite investors still being fearful for the future of the UK economy as the country remains in lockdown and all non-essential travel is banned until at least May 7.

item.title: Classic Ferrari 250 GTE used by the Polizia in Rome in the 1960s is up for sale
item.description: The Ferrari 250 spend six years in service chasing criminals through the streets of Rome, making it the most stylish paddy wagon to have patrolled roads.

item.title: Classic Ferrari 250 GTE used by the Polizia in Rome in the 1960s is up for sale
item.description: The Ferrari 250 spend six years in service chasing criminals through the streets of Rome, making it the most stylish paddy wagon to have patrolled roads.

item.title: People share their DIY disasters as they attempt home improvements during lockdown
item.description: For people all over the world, lockdown has proved the perfect time to get started on some long-awaited home improvement projects - but for some, they didn't go to plan.

item.title: Federal judge DENIES R Kelly's second bid to be released from Chicago jail
item.description: US District Judge Ann Donnelly denied the singer's request to be released from Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) Chicago, where he is being held.

item.title: Can you find the halloumi in this quarantine-themed garden BBQ brainteaser?
item.description: The puzzle, released by British retirement homes Audley Villages, will help transport some players to brighter BBQ days in the sunshine. But can you find the single slice of halloumi?

item.title: Kate Middleton pens a letter to express her 'sincere appreciation' to staff at Action For Children
item.description: Kate Middleton, 38, penned a letter to Action For Children to express her 'sincere gratitude' to staff working on the frontline and behind the scenes during this 'hugely unsettling time.'

item.title: Germany sees daily coronavirus deaths rise to 281
item.description: Today's 281 new deaths are the largest jump since last Friday, bringing Germany's death toll from 4,598 to 4,897.

item.title: Navy deploys TWO warships to South China Sea amid sabre-rattling standoff between Malaysia and China
item.description: The USS America, an amphibious assault ship and the USS Bunker Hill, a guided missile cruiser, have both been deployed and are operating in the South China Sea as China flexes its military muscles.

item.title: Baby elephant leaves perfect impression of his head and trunk in the sand at Chester Zoo
item.description: One-year-old Anjan left this near-perfect imprint of his head and trunk after nodding off in the sand in his enclosure at Chester Zoo. The Asian elephant was named after a conservationist in India.

item.title: Trump says there is NO confirmation North Korean dictator is seriously ill
item.description: President Trump said there is no confirmation that North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un is gravely ill during Tuesday's White House press briefing.

item.title: British nurses at Tavistock Hospital slammed for sharing video performing Haka to coronavirus
item.description: The group performed the traditional Māori war dance in a ward in the Tavistock Hospital in Devon, southwest England over the weekend.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Only 4,900 antibody tests have been carried out
item.description: The UK Government made plans to conduct the 'biggest surveys in the world'. But still, less than 4,300 have taken place at Public Health England's lab, despite the goal of 5,000 per day in April.

item.title: France and Holland are latest nations to re-open schools
item.description: French primary school children are due to return to their classrooms on May 11 with a maximum of around 15 children per class.

item.title: George Alagiah beats coronavirus and gets back to hosting BBC news
item.description: BBC news anchor Raworth, 51, tweeted that her friend and colleague George Alagiah, 64, would be at the helm of Tuesday's 6pm bulletin for the first time after beating coronavirus.

item.title: CIA missed opportunity to kill bin Laden after Clinton signed a bill that forbid intentional killing
item.description: President Clinton said the CIA could engage in 'lethal activity' against bin Laden, but the purpose of the attack couldn't be to kill him, it was revealed in Showtime's Longest War film on Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus: Dyson microbiologist reveals how to keep your home clean and hygienic during COVID-19
item.description: Vacuuming your mattress, washing bed linen at 60°C and dusting walls with a damp cloth once a week will keep your home clean and hygienic during coronavirus, according to microbiologists.

item.title: So THAT'S the secret of your high street treat!
item.description: As the UK remains in lockdown, food writer Rose Prince has taken the nation's favourite high street lunches and made her very own versions of the tasty dishes.

item.title: Ricky Gervais 'likes negative tweet about being "done" with the Beckhams'
item.description: Ricky Gervais has reportedly risked a feud with the Beckham family after 'liking' a negative tweet about being 'done' with the family.

item.title: In these surreal days, nothing is more bizarre than oil prices turning 'negative'
item.description: TOM LEONARD: A hard man strides through a harsh landscape, his face caked in sweat, his calloused hands raw under his driller's gloves. Behind him is an oil derrick.

item.title: The girl who became an icon: ROBERT HARDMAN takes you through the Queen's own unseen photo album
item.description: ROBERT HARDMAN: No peal of bells from an empty Westminster Abbey. No thunderous gun salutes from Hyde Park, the Tower of London, Edinburgh Castle or anywhere else.

item.title: 2,700 cancers MISSED every week: Coronavirus crisis causes urgent GP hospital referrals to plummet
item.description: Cancer Research UK said the numbers being referred by doctors for urgent hospital appointments or checks had dropped by 75 per cent since the start of the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Self-employed and small firms are being denied vital financial support
item.description: Judith Richards, 64, and husband Jason, 57, who offer trike tours cannot get grants worth up to £25,000 because they do not pay business rates.

item.title: Harvard law professor calls homeschooling 'dangerous'
item.description: Harvard law professor, Elizabeth Bartholet (pictured), believes that homeschooling can be 'dangerous' because it gives parents authoritarian control over their children.

item.title: Rogue trader Nick Leeson 'boasts he is doing very well on the stock market'
item.description: The rogue trader, who was jailed for six-and-a-half years after Barings Bank went bust in 1995, insisted 'markets exist through crises' as he confirmed he is 'back trading' in a Facebook post.

item.title: Total coronavirus infections in Italy falls for second day but daily deaths and new cases climb
item.description: The number of new infections in Italy increased to 2,729 from 2,256 today. Despite a drop in the number of patients with the disease, fatalities were up by 534 today from 454 yesterday.

item.title: Prince Charles reveals he watches viral videos during coronavirus lockdown a
item.description: Prince Charles has praised the 'crucial role' of home-grown producers in keeping the country fed and revealed he entertained himself during his time in lockdown by watching funny videos.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: London NHS Nightingale Hospital rejects patients
item.description: The field hospital at the ExCeL Centre in east London (interior pictured) has been unable to accept around 50 coronavirus patients needing 'life or death' care since it opened on April 7.

item.title: Prince William and Kate back new mental health support scheme for key workers called 'Our Frontline'
item.description: William and Kate's Royal Foundation is formally supporting a new initiative, called 'Our Frontline', which will see leading charities and organisations provide mental health support to key workers.

item.title: The fatcat who is now milking our care homes
item.description: GUY ADAMS: The dairy company at the centre of the milk-tipping scandal has been accused of 'disgusting greed' for hiking the amount it charges nursing homes for vital food supplies.

item.title: SARAH VINE: Dear Meghan and Harry, don't worry about us... because we're not worried about you
item.description: SARAH VINE: First of all: how are you both? I know no one ever asks, so I thought it best just to check. After all, it must be so hard for you, stuck in Los Angeles in rented accommodation.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: A world drowning in oil
item.description: One could barely believe the reports when the May price for West Texas crude oil dipped into negative territory late on Monday. The immediate thought was: does this mean free petrol for my car?

item.title: Dozens of homeless people are sleeping at London's deserted Heathrow airport during coronavirus
item.description: One of the rough sleepers at Heathrow Airport, a professional woman in her 40s from west Africa, said the number of homeless people there had doubled since October.

item.title: Coronavirus: Ministers should NOT yet tell public to wear face masks
item.description: Deputy chief medical officer Jonathan Van-Tam said government scientists were ready to change advice to the public on masks if the evidence supported it.

item.title: Prince Harry, Meghan Markle and Archie's video call with Queen
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex were joined by their 11-month-old son Archie Mountbatten-Windsor to speak to Her Majesty this afternoon, a spokesman said.

item.title: Deadly prehistoric crocodiles mimicked whales and dolphins
item.description: Ancient giant crocodiles called thalattosuchians evolved into terrifying ocean predators that mimicked the senses of whales and dolphins, according to new research in Scotland.

item.title: UN warns of 'biblical' famines as coronavirus threatens to leave three dozen nations starving
item.description: The United Nations warned the coronavirus pandemic could trigger famine in already vulnerable countries, forcing 265 million into starvation due to the global crisis.
item.media:description: The pandemic could lead to a "humanitarian catastrophe" with the number of people suffering from acute hunger projected to nearly double to 265 million this year, the UN warned

item.title: Fawlty thinking? British actor John Cleese charges fans £249 to be insulted in four-minute videos
item.description: John Cleese, 80, delighted fans with personalised messages from his hotel room in Beverley Hills - and he only charged them £249 each.

item.title: White House Hot Mic Catches Someone Joking with Fox's John Roberts: 'We've All Been Vaccinated
item.description: A hot mic in the White House briefing room captured a conversation between Fox News reporter John Roberts and New York Times photographer Doug Mills.

item.title: RSPCA hunt ghouls after a cat was tortured to death then BARBECUED in South Yorkshire
item.description: An investigation is underway following the grim discovery of a dead cat opposite a row of shops in Wheatley in Doncaster, South Yorkshire, on Thursday morning.

item.title: The murders most foul: Did the Beast of Belgravia actually butcher ELEVEN people?
item.description: The next of our The murders most foul series looks at three serial killers whose sprees shocked the nation. They include the Beast of Belgravia and the only killer to be hanged during an air raid.

item.title: $41BN Harvard says it will KEEP $8.6M bailout after Trump said they must give it back
item.description: President Trump demanded on Tuesday that Harvard University give taxpayer funds back, citing the Ivy League school's eye-watering $40.9 billion endowment.

item.title: Battle of Britain hero thought to have been inspiration for Tom Hardy's character in Dunkirk
item.description: A Battle of Britain hero thought to have been the real life inspiration for Tom Hardy's character in the film Dunkirk has been revealed after his bravery medals emerged for sale.

item.title: Donald Trump says immigration is 'paused' for 60 days
item.description: President Donald Trump said on Tuesday his immigration ban would be a 60-day pause on green cards, which is already in place because of the coronavirus.

item.title: Protesters in North Carolina, Missouri and Alabama demand an end to lockdown
item.description: Demonstrators gathered in Raleigh, North Carolina, Tuesday to demand Governor Roy Cooper brings an end to the state's coronavirus lockdown rules and reopens the state for business.

item.title: Greta Thunberg launches video of family walking around burning house
item.description: The shocking clip shows a family walking around a burning house at an undisclosed location. It ends with: 'Our house is on fire. React.'

item.title: Bank of England boss Andrew Bailey warns that lifting the lockdown too soon would cause WORSE damage
item.description: In his first interview since taking the top job, Andrew Bailey told the Daily Mail that a premature end to the restrictions could cause a severe loss of confidence and inflict damage on the economy.

item.title: Coronavirus China: Restaurant air con spread illness to nine
item.description: Researchers have investigated an incident at an eatery in Guangzhou, China, where an asymptomatic customer later fell ill, along with others who were sat on nearby tables.

item.title: Shoe addict who owns a collection worth £25,000 moved 500 pairs from London to Scotland
item.description: Katie Porter, 51, revealed she spent a week packing her £25,000 shoe collection of more than 500 pairs when moving from London to Edinburgh, and still wears them everyday during the lockdown.

item.title: Richard Branson's Australian airline collapsed and is begging for bailout to save Virgin Atlantic
item.description: Sir Richard Branson (third from left) is used to private jets, holidaying with politicians and hobnobbing with A-listers, including Barack Obama (top right) and Kate Winslet (bottom right).

item.title: Father of miracle quad babies fights for his life in hospital with coronavirus
item.description: Giovanni Sapia, from Harlow, Essex, was struck down with the bug earlier this month and was critically ill on a ventilator, with only 25% of his heart fully functioning.

item.title: British 'jihadi rapper' was 'snuck into Spain by boat after posing as an undocumented migrant'
item.description: Spanish state broadcaster TVE said the jihadi reached the city of Almeria in a patera, the wooden boats Africans traditionally use to reach Europe from as far afield as Senegal.

item.title: UK's biggest airlines and travel operators are 'flouting the law' by delaying refunds, says Which?
item.description: A survey of the UK's 20 biggest travel firms found that none are refunding customers within the legal time frames. Millions have had holidays cancelled after Britons were advised against all global travel.

item.title: Spain cancels its world-famous Pamplona bull running festival because of coronavirus
item.description: The 3,968 new cases in Spain - down from 4,266 yesterday - bring the total from 200,210 to 204,178, an increase of 2.0 per cent.

item.title: Home listings drop by 82 per cent on average across UK
item.description: The worst affected boroughs in London are Hillingdon and Bromley, which have both seen a 91 per cent drop in listings. Woking, Surrey, is the worst affected place in the UK.

item.title: Are coronavirus lockdown measures slipping after more cars on road than ever on Sunday in outbreak
item.description: Last Sunday (April 19), traffic levels across Britain were just over 30 per cent of what they were in February, which is the highest they have been on a Sunday during the whole of lockdown.

item.title: Hollywood at Home: Intimate portraits of Golden Age stars from Marlon Brando to Audrey Hepburn
item.description: Between 1946 and 1961, photographer Sid Avery shot almost every cinema giant in the mid-twentieth century, capturing Hollywood stars in their most intimate unguarded moments.

item.title: What is the minimal amount of exercise you need to stay healthy during lockdown?
item.description: With Australian gyms remaining closed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it has become more important than ever to maintain your fitness at home.

item.title: Living alone makes over-50s 30% more likely to be treated in hospital for respiratory diseases
item.description: Data from almost 4,500 over-50s in the UK found one in nine people end up in hospital with respiratory problems over time.

item.title: Watching TV for more than 4 hours a day 'linked to poorer heart health'
item.description: Researchers from the University of Groningen scoured DNA of more than 400,000 Britons for genetic locations linked to sedentary behaviour,such as watching TV.

item.title: Jane Horrocks reveals her heartache over her mother's battle with Alzheimer's
item.description: Making audiences laugh will be the last thing on Jane Horrocks's mind as she says her mother's Alzheimer's disease has left her feeling like an 'orphan'.

item.title: Canada killer 'obsessed with mounties' had an alcohol problem
item.description: Gabriel Wortman, the 51-year-old gunman who was shot dead after a 12-hour killing and arson spree across Nova Scotia, was also said to have an obsession with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Matt Hancock insists lockdown must stay
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock vowed not to compromise the national effort against the disease as the daily Downing Street briefing heard cases have 'plateaued' rather than fallen.

item.title: 300,000-year-old hunting sticks found in Germany
item.description: An ancient wooden hunting stick, used by an extinct human sub-species around 300,000 years ago to kill prey, could travel at speeds of nearly 100 feet a second, researchers reveal.

item.title: People share pictures of their VERY successful attempts at making IKEA's meatballs
item.description: Swedish furniture giant IKEA revealed its famous dish is made by mixing pork and beef mince with garlic and onion - and now dozens of people are showing off their DIY efforts on social media.

item.title: Couple who fostered more than 100 children die within weeks of each other
item.description: Barbara Newell, 67, died from lung disease just a month before her husband Allan, 72, contracted coronavirus and passed away in Bradford, West Yorkshire.

item.title: Hilary Mantel pitted against Booker Prize winner Bernardine Evaristo in Women's Prize For Fiction
item.description: Hilary Mantel's (pictured) new novel The Mirror And The Light was published last month and concluded her Thomas Cromwell trilogy. It will go up against Bernardine Evaristo's Girl, Woman, Other.

item.title: On-duty policeman is killed after his motorbike smashed into a car during high-speed pursuit
item.description: A witness who would only give his first name, Jack, 48, said it was 'like a dream' when he heard a 'huge bang' while driving along a road in the Ecclesfield area of Sheffield at 1pm today.

item.title: University of Colorado student tries to set her single mom up with 'babe' professor in viral TikTok
item.description: niversity of Colorado at Boulder student Aly Oliver was preparing for a Zoom class when her mother noticed a photo of one of her professors, and quickly commented on how attractive he was.

item.title: More than 2.5million people are now infected with coronavirus around the world
item.description: Worldwide coronavirus infections surpassed 2.5 million with more than 170,000 deaths globally. US cases are nearing 800,000 and two-thirds of the worldwide figure has been reported in Europe.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Barclays' £750 interest-free overdraft buffer
item.description: Barclays bank is offering customers an interest free deal on pre agreed overdrafts up to £750. Anyone breaching the limit will pay 19.51 per cent interest on the remaining balance.

item.title: Boris Johnson tells Donald Trump of coronavirus recovery
item.description: Boris Johnson, still recuperating at Chequers along with pregnant fiancee Carrie Symonds, told the president that he is 'feeling better and on the road to recovery'.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 17,337 with 873 new fatalities
item.description: Data from the Office for National Statistics, which includes deaths which happen in care homes, shows 13,000 people had died by April 10 but the Government had only announced 9,000 by then.

item.title: Could the MMR vaccine help protect against coronavirus complications?
item.description: Scientists at the University of Cambridge pointed out that the groups most at risk of dying from COVID-19 - those over the age of 65 - were born before widespread MMR vaccination began.

item.title: Judge rules woman in her 20s with learning disabilities should have contraceptive device fitted
item.description: The woman has had several children taken from her care already but is pregnant again and due to give birth soon, specialists at Oxford University Hospitals (pictured) told a Court of Protection judge.

item.title: Hungry birds of prey eye up terrified poodles just the other side of Chile flat's glass window
item.description: Footage shows a couple of huge condors perched outside a woman's flat in South America, looking to feast on the three dogs who bark excitedly from inside.

item.title: Cat squeezes its whole body head first into a vase
item.description: An owner's amusement at her cat's curiosity turned to panic when the cat managed to get its whole body stuck headfirst in a glass vase in Saransk, Mordovia Republic in Russia.

item.title: Father-of-one, 21, took his own life after telling family he would not get through lockdown alone
item.description: Father-of-one Red Gale, whose family are from Lampeter, Cardiganshire, sent a 'goodbye' message to his heartbroken mother Polly and his close friends on Wednesday, April 1.

item.title: Desperate father, 33, resorts to pulling out his own tooth after he couldn't get appointment
item.description: Billy Taylor, 33, from Devon, pulled out his tooth after NHS 111 said that unless he was struggling to breathe, there was nothing they could do to help.

item.title: Savvy mother transforms dull patch of grass into a pink paradise garden… for just £725
item.description: Chrissie Bray, 45, spent two years creating her dream garden in Birmingham. She came up with the idea of a pink paradise outside after being rediagnosed with breast cancer in 2018

item.title: Is THIS what flying economy will look like after the coronavirus crisis?
item.description: Designs have emerged from an Italian firm for two post-coronavirus economy cabin concepts aimed at helping to prevent future pandemics. One takes its inspiration from the two-faced Roman god Janus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Belgian firm makes '100% accurate' antibody test
item.description: Liege-based firm ZenTech plans to roll its foolproof antibody tests in Belgium first before scaling up manufacturing to three million per month so they can be used in other European countries.

item.title: Probe into baby deaths at scandal-hit NHS Trust is now looking at nearly 1,200 cases
item.description: Letters were today sent to 400 families inviting them to participate in the inquiry after more than 90 babies died or suffered severe harm and disability due to medical failings between 1979 and 2017.

item.title: Cupcakes fit for a Queen! Royal pastry chefs release chocolate cupcake recipe
item.description: The recipe, shared by the official Royal Family Twitter and Instagram accounts, reveals how to create 15 cupcakes - iced with either buttercream or royal icing - that can be enjoyed at home.

item.title: Tom Hanks is donating his blood to medical research in hopes of creating a coronavirus 'Hank-ccine'
item.description: The married couple were amongthe first high-profile individu als to contract COVID-19 and they fell ill whilst in Australia where Tom Hanks was filming Baz Luhrmann's Elvis Presley biopic.

item.title: Petrol prices at 'rip-off levels' even before huge oil crash this week
item.description: Howard Cox, founder of FairFuelUK, said the average prices of a litre of unleaded and diesel should be 98p and 106p respectively, but are around 10p higher on average at retailers.

item.title: Mystery of the 1950s Ford Popular unearthed in a back garden is solved
item.description: The 1950s Ford Popular 103E car was unearthed by John Brayshaw, 40, just inches beneath the surface of his lawn when he was digging in his back garden in Heckmondwike, West Yorkshire..

item.title: WhatsApp is to double the number of people that can video chat at the same time
item.description: It's not clear exactly when the new limit will be introduced as it's only being made available as part of the pre-release beta version of the mobile app at the moment.

item.title: Property developer reveals how he made £366K on a West London flat simply by changing the lay-out
item.description: West London developer Ben Wilson said he used the logic that 'a stunning two-bed will sell for more than a compromised three-bed' in London and set about revamping the Earl's Court flat.

item.title: John Lewis sales plunge by up to a third despite online order surge
item.description: John Lewis sales have taken a nose dive after it was forced to shut stores across the country in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Prince Philip's 'passion for science' could be reason for 'very unusual' statement
item.description: The Duke of Edinburgh, 98, was not 'trying to reach out to the nation' with his 'very unusual' public statement yesterday because he 'leaves that to the Queen', Ingrid Seward told Vanity Fair.

item.title: Amazon gives UK warehouse staff a £2-a-hour pay rise
item.description: UK boss Doug Gurr wrote to customers today explaining that the online retail giant has also upgraded its warehouses to Government standards on social distancing.

item.title: National Tea Day sparks debate on 'correct shade' of brew
item.description: Twitter has marked the fifth annual National Tea Day in Britain with a debate on the perfect cup of brew - asking followers what the perfect colour and process is.

item.title: Tiny beetle that attacks ragweed plants could help 'millions of hay fever sufferers'
item.description: By damaging the plants enough that they can't release pollen, the humble leaf beetle - or 'Ophraella communa' - could reduce airborne ragweed pollen by 82 per cent.

item.title: Coronavirus: Sweden hits highest number of daily deaths at 185
item.description: The surge of 185 new deaths in Sweden is likely to be caused by delays in collecting figures from the weekend, a problem which many countries have experienced.

item.title: The UK's biggest family, the Radfords, go on their first family outing in five weeks
item.description: Sue, 44 and Noel Radford, 48, from Lancashire shared an update to their YouTube channel, reavealing they'd been on their first outing with newborn Heidie and some of their 22 children.

item.title: Lady Pamela Hicks shares her memories of Prince Philip's mother Princess Alice
item.description: Lady Pamela Hicks, 90, daughter of Philip's maternal uncle Lord Mountbatten, told how the Queen, 94, has a talent for 'getting the best' out of people in conversation with daughter India Hicks.

item.title: Police hunt Prince Harry lookalike after serious assault in Glasgow left man, 23, in hospital
item.description: Officers in Scotland today released CCTV images of two men they would like to speak to following the assault in Glasgow at around 12.20am on Sunday, February 23.

item.title: Market stall holder blew his mother's £156,000 life savings on the stock market
item.description: A son with 'an addiction to investing and gambling' stole his dementia-stricken mother's £156,000 life savings and lost it on the stock markets. Richard Potter, from Leicester, blew £600,000 over 20 years.

item.title: China 'put thousands to death' in 2019 - far more than any other country
item.description: The human rights watchdog said China 'continued to execute and sentence to death thousands of people' but said the country's exact figures were 'kept secret'.

item.title: The story of Octopussy which broke the 50-knot barrier and became world's fastest superyacht
item.description: A new documentary has revealed how Heesen Yachts turned American businessman John Staluppi's dream of owning the world's fastest superyacht into a reality in 1988.

item.title: Mother's four-ingredient recipe for vanilla bites keeps her kids happy in lockdown
item.description: Adela Lovrencic discovered how to bake a tray of the miniature desserts with a sheet of ready-made puff pastry, milk, icing sugar and a packet of instant vanilla pudding for just $6.85.
item.media:credit: Share Kmart Air Fryer Recipes Australia Facebook

item.title: Boyzone's Shane Lynch SPLITS from wife Sheena White as he moves out of family home
item.description: The singer, 43, and the former backing singer have been married for 13 years and share daughters, Billie, 11, and Marley, 7

item.title: Why can't the elderly go to the empty Nightingales?
item.description: The Birchwood Residential Care Home in Essex was allegedly forced to accept an elderly COVID-19 patient 'against their wishes' before they were re-admitted to hospital the next day.

item.title: Tory health minister Helen Whately sniggers as Piers Morgan asks about 4,000 care home deaths
item.description: The MP insisted that the Government has been working hard, but Piers insisted she answer questions about deaths in care homes, telling her he expected her to be working hard.
